newsitem.title: SIERRA LEONE: Sierra Leone bauxite mine finds potential buyer.
newsitem.headline: Sierra Leone bauxite mine finds potential buyer.

text.p: Sierra Leone's Sieromco bauxite mine, a subsidiary of Alusuisse-Lonza Holding AG has found a potential U.S. buyer who could enable mining to resume, Sieromco's managing director said on Thursday.
James Westwood told Reuters Alusuisse had agreed to sell its shares in Sierra Leone Ore and Metal Co to a U.S. company called Innovest Capital Forces Corp.
Westwood said Alusuisse had agreed to assign Sieromco's lease and operations agreement to Louisiana-based Innovest but the deal still needed government approval. The lease has 10 years remaining.
"We have entered the agreement in good faith and we hope that government approval comes quickly so that operations can resume before there is further deterioration of the mines," Westwood said.
Innovest has financial backing from metals and minerals trader Fuci Metals USA Inc.

Industry sources said other firms who had shown interest in buying the mine included an Iranian company, and local firm Jupiter Export Import Ltd who have a concession in the eastern Port Loko region.

Sieromco began mining bauxite at Mokanji in southern Sierra Leone in 1964. Exports averaged 1.7 million tonnes a year in 1984-88 but declined to 1.3 million tonnes by 1992. The mine was overrun by rebels of the Revolutionary United Front in January 1995 and when the rebel war died down the company decided it was not economically viable to resume.
The company lost an estimated $30 million in assets when the mine was attacked and looted, and industry sources say it has lost a major client in Ukraine.
